questions.stem: Vroom's expectancy theory proposes that motivation is a function of three components. Which of the following correctly identifies all three?

options.text: Need, drive, and incentive
Expectancy (effort-to-performance), instrumentality (performance-to-outcome), and valence (value of outcome)
Goal difficulty, goal specificity, and goal commitment
Autonomy, competence, and relatedness

questions.explanation: Vroom's (1964) VIE (Valence-Instrumentality-Expectancy) theory is a process theory that proposes: Expectancy (E)—the belief that effort will lead to successful performance (probability 0-1); Instrumentality (I)—the belief that performance will lead to specific outcomes (probability -1 to +1); Valence (V)—the desirability or value of those outcomes (positive, negative, or neutral). Motivation = E x I x V. If any component is zero, motivation is zero. This multiplicative relationship means organizations must address all three—effort-performance links, performance-reward links, and reward attractiveness. Option C describes goal-setting theory; D describes self-determination theory.

questions.stem: According to Locke and Latham's goal-setting theory, which type of goals produce the highest performance?

options.text: Easy, vague goals ('do your best')
Specific, difficult (but attainable) goals with feedback
No goals—allowing complete autonomy
Impossible goals that maximize challenge

questions.explanation: Locke and Latham's (1990, 2002) goal-setting theory is one of the most robustly supported theories in I/O psychology. Specific, difficult goals produce higher performance than easy goals, vague goals, or 'do your best' instructions. The mechanisms are: direction (focus attention), effort (energize), persistence, and strategy development. Key moderators include: goal commitment (must accept the goal), feedback (must know progress), task complexity (goals are less effective for complex, novel tasks), and self-efficacy. Impossible goals reduce performance and motivation—goals must be challenging but attainable. Research support exceeds 90% in controlled studies.

questions.stem: Self-Determination Theory (Deci & Ryan) proposes that intrinsic motivation is undermined by external rewards primarily when the rewards are perceived as:

options.text: Informational—providing feedback about competence
Controlling—pressuring the person to think, feel, or act in particular ways
Unexpected and not contingent on behavior
Given for tasks the person has never tried before

questions.explanation: Self-Determination Theory's Cognitive Evaluation Theory (CET) component proposes that external rewards have two aspects: informational (conveying competence feedback) and controlling (pressuring particular behavior). When rewards are perceived as controlling, they undermine intrinsic motivation by shifting perceived locus of causality from internal to external—the person feels they're performing for the reward rather than for enjoyment. When perceived as informational (conveying competence), rewards can maintain or enhance intrinsic motivation. The 'overjustification effect' occurs when tangible, expected, contingent rewards undermine intrinsic interest in tasks that were initially intrinsically motivating.

questions.stem: Adams' equity theory predicts that an employee who perceives underpayment inequity (their input/outcome ratio is less favorable than a referent other's) will most likely:

options.text: Increase their inputs (work harder) to justify higher outcomes
Reduce their inputs, distort perceptions, change the comparison other, or attempt to increase their outcomes
Remain completely unaffected by the perceived inequity
Always immediately quit their job

questions.explanation: Adams' (1965) equity theory predicts that perceived underpayment inequity creates tension that motivates restoration. Common responses include: reducing inputs (decreasing effort—'I'm not going to work that hard for this pay'), attempting to increase outcomes (asking for a raise), distorting perceptions (rationalizing that the referent's job is harder), changing the comparison other (comparing to someone with a less favorable ratio), or leaving the situation (absenteeism, turnover). Research strongly supports that underpayment leads to reduced quantity or quality of work. Overpayment predictions (increasing inputs or reducing outcomes) have received less consistent support.

questions.stem: Bandura's self-efficacy theory proposes that an individual's belief in their ability to succeed at a task is influenced by four primary sources. Which is considered the MOST powerful source?

options.text: Vicarious experience (observing others succeed)
Verbal persuasion (encouragement from others)
Enactive mastery experience (personal success)
Physiological/emotional states (feeling calm vs. anxious)

questions.explanation: Bandura (1977, 1997) identified four sources of self-efficacy, ordered by strength: (1) Enactive mastery (personal performance accomplishments)—the most powerful because direct experience provides the most authentic evidence of capability. (2) Vicarious experience—observing similar others succeed raises self-efficacy ('if they can do it, so can I'). (3) Verbal persuasion—encouragement from credible sources has moderate but temporary effects. (4) Physiological/emotional states—interpretations of arousal (calm = capable; anxious = incapable). In organizational settings, self-efficacy predicts performance, goal-setting, effort, persistence, and resilience to failure. Training programs should build self-efficacy through graduated success experiences.

questions.stem: Self-Determination Theory (Deci & Ryan) identifies three basic psychological needs that, when satisfied, promote intrinsic motivation and well-being. Which are they? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Autonomy—the need for volition and self-regulation
Competence—the need to feel effective and capable
Relatedness—the need for connection and belonging
Power—the need to control others
Wealth—the need for financial accumulation

questions.explanation: SDT (Deci & Ryan, 2000) identifies three basic psychological needs: Autonomy (not independence, but volition—feeling one's actions are self-endorsed), Competence (feeling effective in interactions with the environment), and Relatedness (feeling connected to and cared for by others). When these needs are satisfied, intrinsic motivation, internalization of extrinsic motivation, well-being, and performance increase. Need frustration leads to amotivation, controlled motivation, and ill-being. Power (D) is from McClelland's need theory, and wealth (E) is not a recognized basic psychological need in SDT.

questions.stem: According to goal-setting theory, which of the following are recognized moderators that affect the goal-performance relationship? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Goal commitment—the degree to which the person is dedicated to achieving the goal
Feedback—information about progress toward the goal
Task complexity—goals are less effective for highly complex, novel tasks
Self-efficacy—belief in one's ability to achieve the goal
The color of the paper the goal is written on

questions.explanation: Goal-setting theory moderators: Goal commitment (A)—without commitment, goals have no effect; commitment is enhanced by importance and self-efficacy. Feedback (B)—goals plus feedback are more effective than either alone; feedback allows self-regulation and strategy adjustment. Task complexity (C)—for complex tasks, specific goals can impair performance by narrowing attention; 'do your best' or learning goals may be more appropriate. Self-efficacy (D)—high self-efficacy enhances goal choice, commitment, and persistence. Additionally, ability and situational constraints moderate the relationship. The color of paper (E) has no theoretical relevance.

questions.stem: McClelland's acquired needs theory identifies three needs that drive behavior. Which of the following are correct descriptions? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Need for Achievement (nAch)—desire to excel and accomplish challenging tasks
Need for Power (nPow)—desire to influence and control others
Need for Affiliation (nAff)—desire for close relationships and approval
High nAch individuals prefer tasks of moderate difficulty with personal responsibility
McClelland argued these needs are entirely innate and cannot be learned

questions.explanation: McClelland's theory: nAch—desire for excellence, preference for moderate challenge, personal responsibility, and concrete feedback (A, D). nPow—desire to influence, direct, or control others; can be personalized (self-serving) or socialized (benefiting the organization) (B). nAff—desire for warm, friendly relationships and approval from others (C). McClelland argued these needs are acquired (learned) through socialization, not innate (E is incorrect)—they can be developed through achievement motivation training. McClelland used the Thematic Apperception Test (TAT) to measure these implicit motives. High nPow combined with low nAff and high activity inhibition predicts managerial success.

questions.stem: Research on organizational behavior modification (OB Mod) based on reinforcement theory has found which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Positive reinforcement is more effective than punishment for sustaining behavior change
Variable ratio schedules of reinforcement produce the highest and most resistant response rates
Continuous reinforcement is best for maintaining established behavior
Extinction (removing reinforcement) can be used to decrease undesirable behaviors
OB Mod interventions have shown positive effects on performance in meta-analyses

questions.explanation: OB Mod (Luthans & Kreitner) applies reinforcement principles to workplace behavior: Positive reinforcement is generally more effective and sustainable than punishment (A). Variable ratio schedules produce the highest, most consistent, and most extinction-resistant response rates (B). Continuous reinforcement is best for acquiring new behavior, not maintaining it (C is incorrect)—intermittent schedules maintain behavior better. Extinction (removing reinforcement for undesired behavior) is effective when combined with reinforcement of desired alternatives (D). Meta-analyses (Stajkovic & Luthans, 1997) showed a 17% average performance improvement from OB Mod interventions (E).

questions.stem: Regarding the relationship between Maslow's hierarchy and Alderfer's ERG theory, which statements are accurate? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Alderfer condensed Maslow's five levels into three: Existence, Relatedness, and Growth
ERG theory allows for multiple needs to be active simultaneously
ERG theory includes a 'frustration-regression' principle—frustration of higher needs activates lower needs
Both theories propose a strict hierarchy where lower needs must be completely satisfied before higher needs emerge
ERG theory is generally considered more flexible and empirically supported than Maslow's hierarchy

questions.explanation: Alderfer's (1969) ERG theory: Condensed Maslow's five levels to three—Existence (physiological + safety), Relatedness (social + esteem-external), Growth (esteem-internal + self-actualization) (A). ERG allows multiple needs simultaneously, not requiring strict sequential satisfaction (B). The frustration-regression principle is unique to ERG—when a higher need is frustrated, people regress to intensifying lower-level needs (C). This is more flexible than Maslow's prepotency hypothesis. D is incorrect—while Maslow proposed strict hierarchy, ERG explicitly rejected this. ERG is generally considered more empirically supported (E), though both content theories have limited overall empirical support compared to process theories.

questions.stem: Match each motivation theory to its theoretical classification:

columns.text: Process theory—describes HOW motivation occurs through expectations
Process theory—describes HOW motivation occurs through social comparison
Process theory—describes HOW motivation occurs through goal mechanisms

questions.explanation: Content theories describe what motivates people (identifying specific needs): Maslow's hierarchy (physiological, safety, social, esteem, self-actualization), Herzberg's two-factor, McClelland's acquired needs, Alderfer's ERG. Process theories describe how motivation works: Vroom's expectancy theory (motivation through effort-performance-outcome expectations), Adams' equity theory (motivation through social comparison of input/outcome ratios), and Locke's goal-setting theory (motivation through specific, challenging goals that direct attention, effort, persistence, and strategy). Understanding both what and how is essential for designing effective motivation systems.

questions.stem: Match each SDT motivational regulation to its position on the self-determination continuum:

columns.text: Most self-determined—doing an activity for its inherent enjoyment
Moderately self-determined—the activity aligns with personal values
Least self-determined—acting to obtain rewards or avoid punishment
Absence of motivation—no intention to act

questions.explanation: SDT's Organismic Integration Theory describes a continuum from amotivation to intrinsic motivation. External regulation is the least self-determined form of extrinsic motivation (acting for rewards/punishments). Introjected regulation (not listed) involves internal pressure (guilt, ego). Identified regulation is moderately self-determined—the person consciously values the activity's goals and identifies with its importance. Integrated regulation (most self-determined extrinsic) involves full assimilation with one's values. Intrinsic motivation is fully self-determined—engaging for inherent interest and enjoyment. More self-determined forms predict better performance, persistence, well-being, and creativity.

questions.stem: For each motivation theory, select ALL practical implications for organizations:

columns.text: Set specific, challenging, attainable goals with feedback
Ensure effort-performance links through training and resources
Support autonomy, competence, and relatedness in the workplace
Clarify that valued rewards follow from performance
Avoid excessive external control that undermines intrinsic interest

questions.explanation: Goal-setting: Set SMART goals (specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, time-bound) with feedback loops. Expectancy theory: Strengthen all three links—ensure people believe effort leads to performance (training, resources), performance leads to outcomes (clear reward systems), and outcomes are valued (offer desired rewards). SDT: Design workplaces that support autonomy (choice, input), competence (optimal challenge, positive feedback), and relatedness (teamwork, belonging), while avoiding controlling reward structures that undermine intrinsic motivation. Each theory implies different but complementary organizational interventions.

questions.stem: For each type of reinforcement schedule, select ALL characteristics that describe it:

columns.text: Best for initial learning/acquisition of new behavior
Produces the highest and most consistent response rate
Produces scallop pattern—low responding after reinforcement, acceleration before next delivery

questions.explanation: CRF (every response reinforced): Best for acquisition—new behavior is learned fastest. But produces rapid extinction when reinforcement stops because the change is immediately noticeable. VR (reinforcement after an unpredictable number of responses, e.g., gambling): Produces the highest, most consistent response rates and is most resistant to extinction because the person never knows which response will be reinforced. FI (reinforcement after a fixed time period, e.g., weekly paycheck): Produces a 'scallop' pattern—responding drops after reinforcement and accelerates as the next interval approaches. Organizational applications: Use CRF to establish new behaviors, then switch to intermittent (VR) to maintain them.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about expectancy theory:

Vroom's expectancy theory is a [BLANK1] theory that explains the cognitive process of motivation. The three components are multiplied together: Motivation = [BLANK2]. Expectancy can be increased by improving employee [BLANK3] and providing adequate resources. Instrumentality is strengthened by ensuring clear and consistent links between [BLANK4]. Valence varies across individuals because different employees value different [BLANK5]. A critical implication is that if any component is zero, motivation will be zero regardless of the other components.
questions.explanation: Expectancy theory is a cognitive/process theory. The multiplicative relationship (E x I x V) means all three must be positive for motivation. Expectancy is increased through training, resources, and building self-efficacy. Instrumentality requires clear, consistent, credible performance-reward connections. Valence varies across individuals—some value pay, others flexibility, recognition, or growth. The multiplicative relationship explains why offering a valued reward (high V) fails to motivate if the employee doesn't believe effort leads to performance (low E) or performance leads to the reward (low I).

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Locke and Latham's goal-setting theory:

Goal-setting theory proposes that [BLANK1] goals produce higher performance than vague or easy goals. Goals affect performance through four mechanisms: directing [BLANK2], energizing effort, increasing persistence, and promoting the development of task-relevant [BLANK3]. The theory distinguishes between performance goals (achieving a specific level) and [BLANK4] goals (developing strategies and skills), with the latter being more effective for complex tasks. A potential 'dark side' of goal-setting includes the risk that overly narrow goals can promote [BLANK5] behavior and tunnel vision.
questions.explanation: Goal-setting theory: Specific, difficult goals outperform other types across hundreds of studies. The four mechanisms: attention (focus on goal-relevant activities), effort (energization), persistence (sustained effort over time), and strategy development (developing task approaches). Learning goals ('develop three new strategies') are more effective than performance goals ('achieve X level') for complex, novel tasks because they focus on skill development rather than outcome achievement. Ordonez et al. (2009) cautioned about the 'dark side': overly narrow, aggressive goals can promote unethical behavior (gaming, cheating), tunnel vision (neglecting unmeasured dimensions), and excessive risk-taking.

questions.stem: A sales team is offered large bonuses for meeting quarterly sales targets. Initially, sales increase dramatically. However, after six months, the team discovers that salespeople have been overpromising to customers, neglecting service quality, and in some cases falsifying order data to meet targets.
questions.centerQuestion: What motivational concept best explains these unintended negative consequences?

options.text: Specific, aggressive goals combined with strong financial incentives created tunnel vision
The reward system focused on a single metric (sales volume) while ignoring service quality
High instrumentality for the outcome created pressure that overrode ethical standards
The goals were too easy and didn't challenge the salespeople
Use multiple metrics (sales, service quality, customer satisfaction) in the goal system
Establish ethical boundaries that cannot be violated regardless of goal attainment
Make the bonuses even larger to increase motivation further
Include learning goals alongside performance goals

centerOptions.text: The 'dark side' of goal-setting—narrow goals creating unethical behavior and tunnel vision

questions.explanation: This illustrates Ordonez et al.'s (2009) 'dark side of goal-setting' and Kerr's (1975) 'folly of rewarding A while hoping for B.' Narrow, aggressive sales goals with high-stakes incentives created: tunnel vision (neglecting unmeasured dimensions like service quality), unethical behavior (falsifying data to meet targets), and excessive risk-taking (overpromising). Solutions include: multiple balanced metrics (balanced scorecard approach), clear ethical boundaries (non-negotiable standards), and learning goals that encourage sustainable skill development. The problem isn't goal-setting itself but poorly designed goal systems with insufficient safeguards.

questions.stem: A software company introduces a mandatory gamification system that awards points, badges, and leaderboard rankings for completing coding tasks. Developers who previously enjoyed coding and took pride in elegant solutions now report feeling controlled and 'just grinding for points.' Several senior developers have become less innovative.
questions.centerQuestion: What motivational theory best explains the decrease in intrinsic motivation?

options.text: External rewards perceived as controlling shifted perceived locus of causality from internal to external
The gamification system undermined autonomy by prescribing how and when to code
Leaderboards created social comparison pressure, undermining relatedness
The rewards were simply not large enough
Make gamification optional and allow developers to choose their own metrics
Redesign to provide informational feedback on competence rather than controlling comparisons
Increase the point values to further incentivize completion
Support intrinsic interest by allowing autonomy in project selection and methods

centerOptions.text: SDT's overjustification effect—controlling external rewards undermining pre-existing intrinsic motivation
Goal-setting theory—the goals were too easy

questions.explanation: This is a classic case of the overjustification effect (Deci & Ryan's Cognitive Evaluation Theory). Developers who were intrinsically motivated (enjoyed coding for its own sake) experienced the gamification as controlling (undermining autonomy), reducing perceived locus of causality from internal to external. Leaderboards created competitive social comparison, undermining relatedness. SDT predicts that intrinsic motivation will decrease when autonomy, competence, and relatedness needs are thwarted. Solutions should restore autonomy (choice), provide informational rather than controlling feedback, and de-emphasize external comparison. Increasing rewards would worsen the problem.

questions.stem: A management professor is reviewing motivation theories. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Maslow's hierarchy of needs has received strong, consistent empirical support for the strict prepotency hypothesis. (B) Goal-setting theory is one of the most empirically supported theories in organizational behavior. (C) Vroom's expectancy theory uses a multiplicative model—if any component (E, I, or V) is zero, motivation is zero. (D) Adams' equity theory predicts that overpaid employees will always work harder. (E) Reinforcement theory (Skinner) is a cognitive theory that focuses on internal mental processes. (F) McClelland argued that achievement motivation can be developed through training.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (B) Goal-setting theory has extensive empirical support (~90% of studies). (C) Expectancy theory's multiplicative model means zero on any component eliminates motivation. (F) McClelland demonstrated that nAch can be increased through achievement motivation training programs. Incorrect: (A) Maslow's strict hierarchy has NOT received strong empirical support—the need order is not consistently supported. (D) Equity theory predicts overpayment leads to increased inputs OR distorted perceptions—not always harder work, and the effect is inconsistent. (E) Reinforcement theory is explicitly non-cognitive—it focuses on environmental contingencies, not internal mental processes.

questions.stem: An organizational consultant is designing a motivation program. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) According to SDT, supporting employee autonomy enhances intrinsic motivation and internalization of extrinsic motivation. (B) Research shows that 'do your best' goals produce higher performance than specific, difficult goals. (C) Equity theory suggests that perceptions of fairness, not just absolute outcomes, affect motivation. (D) The Premack principle states that a more preferred activity can reinforce a less preferred activity. (E) Self-efficacy beliefs affect goal choice, effort, and persistence in the face of obstacles. (F) Punishment is the most effective long-term strategy for maintaining behavior change. (G) Herzberg's motivator-hygiene theory suggests that improving pay alone will not produce genuine job satisfaction.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) SDT research robustly supports autonomy support for motivation. (C) Equity theory's core insight is that perceived fairness of the input/outcome ratio matters. (E) Bandura's self-efficacy theory shows these predictive relationships. (G) Herzberg argues pay (hygiene factor) prevents dissatisfaction but doesn't create satisfaction. Incorrect: (B) The opposite—specific, difficult goals consistently outperform 'do your best' goals. (D) While the Premack principle is accurate psychology, it was less clearly relevant to the consultant context compared to other options. (F) Punishment has short-term effects but produces side effects (resentment, avoidance, aggression) and is less effective than positive reinforcement for long-term change.

questions.stem: Arrange Maslow's hierarchy of needs from the most basic (bottom) to the highest (top):

options.text: Self-actualization (realizing full potential)
Physiological needs (food, water, shelter)
Esteem needs (achievement, recognition, respect)
Safety needs (security, stability, protection)
Belongingness and love needs (relationships, affiliation)

questions.explanation: Maslow's (1943, 1954) hierarchy from most basic to highest: (1) Physiological—basic survival needs. (2) Safety—security, stability, freedom from threat. (3) Belongingness/Love—social connections, intimacy, group membership. (4) Esteem—self-esteem (competence, achievement) and esteem from others (recognition, status). (5) Self-actualization—realizing one's full potential, becoming everything one is capable of being. Maslow proposed prepotency—lower needs must be substantially satisfied before higher needs become motivating. While the hierarchy is intuitively appealing and widely known, empirical support for the strict hierarchical ordering is limited.

questions.stem: Arrange the SDT self-determination continuum from LEAST self-determined to MOST self-determined:

options.text: Intrinsic motivation (inherent interest and enjoyment)
External regulation (acting for rewards or to avoid punishment)
Identified regulation (consciously valuing the activity's importance)
Amotivation (no motivation or intention to act)
Introjected regulation (internal pressure: guilt, ego involvement)

questions.explanation: SDT's self-determination continuum (Deci & Ryan, 2000): (1) Amotivation—no intention to act, learned helplessness. (2) External regulation—acting for tangible rewards or to avoid punishment (most controlled extrinsic motivation). (3) Introjected regulation—partially internalized but still controlled by internal pressures (guilt, pride, ego). (4) Identified regulation—conscious valuing of the activity's importance ('I exercise because health is important to me'). (5) Intrinsic motivation—engaging for inherent enjoyment and interest. Integrated regulation (not listed) falls between identified and intrinsic. Movement toward more self-determined forms requires satisfaction of autonomy, competence, and relatedness needs.

questions.stem: Review data from goal-setting research on the relationship between goal difficulty and performance:

questions.question: What is the relationship between goal difficulty and performance?

options.text: Performance increases linearly without limit as goals get harder
Performance increases with difficulty up to a point, then decreases when goals become unrealistic and commitment drops
Easy goals produce the highest performance
Goal difficulty has no effect on performance

questions.question: Why does performance decline at the 'very difficult' level?

options.text: Workers are too motivated
Goal commitment drops sharply when goals are perceived as unattainable
Very difficult goals are identical to easy goals
Performance always declines with any difficulty increase

questions.explanation: The data illustrate Locke and Latham's findings: performance increases with goal difficulty—but only as long as commitment is maintained. When goals become perceived as unattainable (very difficult/near-impossible), commitment drops dramatically (from 6 to 3), and performance declines. This is why the theory specifies 'difficult but attainable' goals. The key moderator is goal commitment—without it, goal difficulty has no positive effect. Commitment is maintained when people believe the goal is achievable (self-efficacy), the goal is important (value), and there is support for goal attainment. The relationship is linear up to the commitment boundary.

questions.stem: Examine data on the effects of different reward systems on intrinsic motivation (measured as free-choice persistence after reward removal):

datasets.name: Free-choice persistence (minutes, higher = more intrinsic motivation)

questions.question: Which reward condition shows the strongest undermining of intrinsic motivation?

options.text: Verbal praise
Expected tangible reward
Unexpected tangible reward
Performance-contingent informational feedback

questions.question: These findings are most consistent with which theoretical prediction?

options.text: Reinforcement theory—all rewards increase future behavior
SDT's Cognitive Evaluation Theory—expected tangible rewards perceived as controlling undermine intrinsic motivation
Goal-setting theory—rewards substitute for goals
Equity theory—rewards create inequity

questions.explanation: The data support SDT's Cognitive Evaluation Theory: Expected tangible rewards (8 minutes vs. 15 baseline) significantly undermined intrinsic motivation—the overjustification effect. Unexpected tangible rewards (14 minutes) had minimal effect because they weren't perceived as controlling (the person didn't initially perform for the reward). Verbal praise (18 minutes) and informational feedback (17 minutes) actually enhanced intrinsic motivation because they satisfied competence needs without undermining autonomy. This pattern is consistent with Deci et al.'s (1999) meta-analysis: the undermining effect is specific to expected, tangible, contingent rewards; informational feedback enhances intrinsic motivation.

questions.stem: Categorize each motivation theory as either a content theory or a process theory:
questions.explanation: Content theories identify what motivates people by specifying needs or factors: Maslow (five hierarchical needs), Herzberg (motivators vs. hygiene factors), McClelland (achievement, power, affiliation), and Alderfer (existence, relatedness, growth). Process theories explain how motivation occurs through cognitive mechanisms: Vroom (expectancy-instrumentality-valence calculations), Adams (equity comparison of input/outcome ratios), Locke (goal mechanisms directing attention, effort, persistence, and strategy), and Bandura (self-efficacy beliefs affecting goal choice, effort, and persistence). Both types are needed for comprehensive understanding.

questions.stem: Categorize each workplace practice according to which SDT basic need it primarily supports:

items.text: Allowing employees to choose their work methods and schedule
Providing constructive feedback on performance progress
Building strong team connections through collaborative projects
Offering meaningful choices in task assignments
Providing optimal challenge through progressively difficult tasks
Creating a psychologically safe environment for expressing ideas
Explaining the rationale behind organizational decisions
Recognizing and celebrating team achievements together

questions.explanation: Autonomy support: Providing choice in methods and schedules, offering meaningful task choices, and explaining rationale (acknowledging the person's perspective) all support the need for volition and self-regulation. Competence support: Constructive feedback enables learning and improvement; optimal challenge (progressive difficulty) builds competence without overwhelming. Relatedness support: Collaborative projects, psychological safety, and shared celebrations all build connection, belonging, and mutual care. SDT research shows that workplaces supporting all three needs produce higher intrinsic motivation, engagement, well-being, and performance.
